title: How to Paint Wall Art for a Kid's Room

steps.headline: Paint simple shapes in complimentary colors for a room belonging to an infant or young toddler.
steps.description: Think basic shapes, ABCs, and simple trees and flowers. Use either pastels or strong colors, but avoid bright, neon shades that may overwhelm your young child.

steps.headline: Introduce animals into the design for older toddlers.
steps.description: Skip the pastels and neon shades, and stick with strong, eye-catching hues.

steps.headline: Play to an older child's interests.
steps.description: Once your kid reaches school age, he or she will likely have his or her own interests and obsessions. Interests often include anything from animals to cityscapes and ballerinas to sports. Build a theme around your child's interests and paint wall art specifically tailored to those interests.

steps.headline: Opt for simple, sophisticated designs once your child reaches the "tween" and "teen" stage.
steps.description: Images that use simple shapes and abstract designs will likely appeal to your maturing child more than specific pictures. Use muted colors or bright, funky shades depending on your child's personality.

steps.headline: Sketch your idea on the wall using light pencil strokes.
steps.description: Use a blue pencil with an eraser. If you cannot find a blue pencil, use a regular pencil with an eraser, instead.

steps.headline: Use painters tape to section your illustration off.
steps.description: Tape is especially useful if you want to create straight lines, and sectioning your illustration off will prevent you from accidentally getting the wrong color on the wrong portion of the illustration.

steps.headline: Pour your paint onto a paint palette.
steps.description: Use acrylic paints and start with colors you know you will use to complete the first section instead of pouring out all the paint at once. This will prevent your paint from drying unnecessarily before use.

steps.headline: Carefully fill in your picture with paint.
steps.description: Use a thin paintbrush to provide yourself with more control.

steps.headline: Wait 24 hours for the first section of paint to dry.
Apply an acrylic sealer to the paint.
steps.description: Remove your painting tape and allow the sealer to dry.

steps.headline: Reapply painters tape to unveil another section of your illustration.
steps.description: Paint and seal the paint using the same method you used for the first section. Repeat as necessary until all sections are complete.

steps.headline: Find stencils that suit the theme of the room.
steps.description: You should search for large stencils, rather than smaller ones, in order to create a noticeable design that stands out as soon as you enter the room. It may be easiest to use stencils specifically made for use with wall paint, since they usually come in finished designs.

steps.headline: Fix the stencil flat on the wall using blue painters tape.
steps.description: Painters tape is strong enough to hold the stencil in place but will not ruin the paint already on the wall.

steps.headline: Pour your paint into a painting tray.
steps.description: You may use standard wall paint, but acrylic craft paint will likely be more cost-effective, especially if you plan on using multiple colors.

steps.headline: Use a paint roller if your design only requires a single color.
steps.description: Coat the roller in your paint and roll the paint over the entire stencil until the entire design has been filled in.

steps.headline: Use a paint brush if applying multiple colors.
steps.description: A stubby stenciling brush works best and creates an "orange peel" finish, a slightly bumpy texture that mimics the texture of an orange peel.

steps.headline: Allow the paint to dry for 24 hours.
Apply an acrylic paint sealer if you used acrylic paint.
steps.description: Opt for a satin finish over a glossy one. Allow the sealer to dry, and air the room out before moving your child's belongings back into the room.

steps.headline: Find a photograph or picture that you want to display on your child's wall.
steps.description: Search for images that consist of "coloring book" outlines for the best result. Full-color pictures can also work, but may be slightly more difficult to paint.

steps.headline: Create a digital copy of the picture.
steps.description: If you found the image in a printed source, scan or transfer it into your computer. If you found it online, simply save a copy of the file to your computer.

steps.headline: Rent a projector.
steps.description: You can ask your local library if they offer projector rentals, but more likely than not, you will need to find a store that specializes in renting audio visual equipment.

steps.headline: Print the image onto transparency paper.
steps.description: If you rented a projector that requires the use of transparencies, you need to transfer your image onto a transparency. You can purchase clear transparency paper for your home printer at most office supply stores. If you rent a projector that hooks up to your computer directly, you do not need to print out a transparency.

steps.headline: Position the projector so that it transfers the image onto your selected space.
steps.description: Adjust the position and projection size as necessary until you feel satisfied with the way the image looks on the wall.

steps.headline: Lightly trace the outline of the image using a blue pencil.
steps.description: Redraw every line you wish to duplicate on the mural.

steps.headline: Turn the projector off.
steps.description: Check the image to make sure that you copied everything correctly. If not, turn the projector back on and finish filling in any details you missed.

steps.headline: Spread the paint you need onto a paint palette.
steps.description: Use acrylic craft paint for the best results.

steps.headline: Carefully paint inside the lines using a paintbrush.
steps.description:
Choose a paintbrush that has an appropriate thickness for the size of the picture. A brush that is too small will cause the process to go slower and may increase streaking in the final picture. A brush that is too large may cause you to make more mistakes and paint outside the lines. steps.headline: Let your paint dry for 24 hours after completing the mural.
Seal the mural with acrylic paint sealer.
steps.description: Use a sealer with a satin finish instead of one with a glossy finish.

steps.headline: Vacate the room until the sealer dries.
steps.description: Give the room a chance to air out before moving furniture back into it.
